Gametogenesis.questionText: All the following definitions ate correct except:
options: Gametogenesis, means process of formation of functioning gametes.
Fertilization, means process of union of the 2 gametes to form zygote.
Gastrulation, means formation of the primitive embryonic layers.
Segmentation, is division of embryonic layers to form blastocyst.
Organogenesis, means the formation of different body organs.

Gametogenesis.questionText: All the following structures have habloid number of chromosomes except:
Process of gametogenesis includes all the following steps except:
options: Proliferation of the primitive germ cells by repeated mitotic divisions.
Fusion of the corresponding chromosomes to increase genetic material.
Growth of the primitive germ cells to increase their sizes.
Maturation of the primitive germ cells by meiotic divisions.
Additional process of spermiogenesis added in males.

Gametogenesis.questionText: Regarding spermato genesis, all the following statements are true except:
options: It includes all steps of transformation of spermatogonia into sperma.
Its site is in both testes.

Gametogenesis.questionText: The following are the different parts of sperm except:
The seminal fluid is characterized by all the following except:
options: The normal amount of each ejaculate is about 3-5 C.C.
The seminal secretions are from "seminal vesicle 60%, bulbo-urethral gland 10% & prostate gland 30%".
It is alkaline in reaction due to its fructose & vitamin c.
Spermatic viability is about 2-4 days & abnormal forms not exceed 20%

Gametogenesis.questionText: All the following cells have 23 chromosomes except:
All the following cells have 46 chromosomes except:
Usually one spermatogonium gives:
The sperms usually pass through all the following ducts except:
Regarding the process of oogenesis, one statement is false:
options: Starts during fetal life, contiues after pubertity & after fertilization,
In fetal life "at 3rd month", the oogonia will form 1ry oocytes.
Its site is in the cortex of the ovary,
Number of 1ry oocytes for each ovary at birth is 700,000-2,000,000.
At puberty 1ry oocytes reached 150 meiotic divisions.

Gametogenesis.questionText: All the followings are postpubertal oogenetic changes except:
options: Follicular cells proliferate to form stratum granulosum.
Zona pellucida appeared separating the 1ry oocyte from granulosa cells,
stromal cells arranged into 2 theca layers "interna & externa"
Follicular antrum appears dividing follicular cells into 3 partitions.
With each ovarian cycle, only one follicle reaches full maturity.

Gametogenesis.questionText: For the mature ovum, one statement is false:
options: Its shape is oval & size is 120-150 micron in diameter.
Its inner layer is thin vitelline membrane.
Then there is the previtelline space.

Gametogenesis.questionText: Regarding formation of sperms.
options: Starts at birth and stopped at old age.
Starts at birth and stopped at puberty.
Starts at puberty and continues till old age.
Starts at old age and continues till death.

Gametogenesis.questionText: Regarding oogenesis.
options: Starts at puberty and continues till menopause.
Starts at birth and continues till menopause.
Starts at birth and continues till puberty.
Starts in the intra-uterine life; then arrested to be continued at puberty.

Gametogenesis.questionText: One of the following parts of sperm is responsible for production of energy
Movement of the sperm depends on
Sperm receptors are present on
........... Is the outer cover of the mature ovum
Regarding the sperm, one of the following statements is correct:
options: The nucleus carries 22 autosomes and either X- or Y-chromosome.
Acrosomal cap covers most of the middle piece.

Gametogenesis.questionText: Regarding the ovum, one of the following statements is correct:
options: The nucleus carries 22 autosomes and either X- or Y-chromosome.
Corona radiata is the outer cover of the ovum.

Gametogenesis.questionText: Which of the following cells contains a haploid number of chromosomes?

Female Cycles.questionText: Regarding ovulation, all statements are true except:
options: Its usual onset is on the 14th day of menstrual cycle.
Its usual signs are middle pain with mild raise of basal temperature.
At its start 1st reduction divisions occurs leading to 2ry oocyte.
At ovulation mature follicle ruptured to release mature ovum.
The mature ovum will be surrounded with a layer of corona radiata.

Female Cycles.questionText: For the follicular stage of ovarian cycle all are true except:
options: It starts after birth & repeated every 28 days till menopause.
its site is the cortex of the ovary, under the effect of FSH hormone.
it includes all growth changes in follicular cells till mature follicle.
The follicular cells & theca interna cells are the sources of estrogen hormone.
Estrogen hormone will stimulate pituitary gland to secrete LH.

Female Cycles.questionText: Regarding luteal phase of ovarian cycle, one statement is false
options: It will follow ovulation & leading to formation of corpus luteum.
Corpus luteum will secrete progesterone & estrogen hormones.
With fertilization, HCG hormone leads to more growth of corpus luteum with an increase in its hormonal secretion.
Corpus luteum will continue functioning till placental formation.
Without fertilization corpus luteum turned into corpus heamoragicum then into corpus albicans.

Female Cycles.questionText: For uterine cycle, all are true except
options: Starts from the end of bleeding of cycle till start of next cycle.

Female Cycles.questionText: For stage of menstruation of uterine cycle, one statement is false
options: Amount of blood lost is 50-70 C.C.
Formed of clotted blood & pieces of endometrium.
Endometrial thickness will be about 0.5 mm.
Cervical mucosa does not share in menstrual bleeding.

Female Cycles.questionText: Regarding stages of repair & proliferation, all are true except
options: Stage of repair lasts only 3 days while that of proliferation lasts 7 days.
In repair the bases of uterine glands divided to cover raw endometrium.
In proliferation, the uterine glands become longer, convoluted & loaded with secretion.
Both repair & proliferation are under the control of estrogen hormone.
The source of estrogen hormone is theca interna of Graffian follicle.

Female Cycles.questionText: Concerning stage of secretion, one statement is false
options: Its duration is from 17th day to 28th day of menstruation.
Its endometrium becomes thicker, soft & differentiated into 3 layers.
The uterine glands become more convoluted & full of secretion.
The spiral arteries become dilated & tortuous.
This stage is under control of estrogen, progesterone & LH hormones.

Female Cycles.questionText: All the following are steps of menstruation except
options: It starts by sudden decrease in ovarian hormones by failed fertilization.
This will be followed by intermittent vascular constriction.
The 3 layers of endometrium will suffer from ischemia & shedded.
Blood begins to seep through the ruptured vascular wall.
Pieces of shedded endometrium with escaped blood form menstruation.

Female Cycles.questionText: All the following are post-ovulatory changes except:
options: The follicular cells will undergo lutinization by fat deposition.
After lutinization, progesterone hormone will be secreted.
With fertilization corpus luteum persisted till placental development.
Without fertilization the corpus luteum degenerates & fibrosed.
With fertilization 2ry meiosis is completed to get ovum & 1st polar body.

Fertilization.questionText: For fertilization, all are true except:
options: It means union of male& female gametes
Its aim is to form zygote.
May be external as in fish.
May be internal as in mammals.
Its site is medial end of uterine tube.

Fertilization.questionText: Process of fertilization has all the following preparatory steps except:
options: Sperms reach uterine tube by uterine contraction.
The sperms undergo process of capacitation.
Before spermatic penetration, there is an acrosomal reaction.
Finally the sperms undergo its meiotic divisions.

Fertilization.questionText: Regarding process of capacitation, all are true except:
options: It means removing of the glycoprotein cover from the spermatic surface.
It occurs in the female genital tract.
It allows the occurrence of acrosomal reaction.
It is inhibited by the presence of progesterone hormone.

Fertilization.questionText: All the following are steps of the process of fertilization Except:
options: Phase "1", penetration of the corona radiate by hyaluronidase enzyme.
Phase"2", penetration of zona pellucida by different lysin enzymes.
The head of sperm becomes rounded to form male pronucleus.
Oocyte response, will complete 2nd reduction division.
Finally the sperm will release inhibitory substance preventing new penetration of new sperms.

Fertilization.questionText: Fertilization will give the following results except:
options: Restoration of diploid number of chromosomes.
Sex determination either male offspring or female offspring.
Transportation of the parent characters to the fetus.

Fertilization.questionText: Regarding the fertilization, one of the following is true:
options: One sperm only penetrates the corona radiate
The fertilization is normally occurs in the medial third of uterine tube
it's the union of sperm and ovum to form the zygote
Increase the amount of acrosomal enzymes.
Removal of glycoprotein coat from the head of the sperm.
Penetration of cell membrane of ovum.
Penetration of cell membrane of ovum.
Is the sperm penetration of zona pellucida.
Occurs by release of lysosomal enzymes from cortical granules of the ovum.
Occurs after capacitation of the sperms.
Is the degeneration of zona pellucida.
After passage of sperms through corona radiate.
During sperm penetration of zona pellucida.
After entrance of the sperm to the cytoplasm of the ovum.

Fertilization.questionText: One of the following is a result of fertilization.
options: Formation of male and female pronuclei.
Zygote nucleus contains haploid number of chromosomes.

Implantation.questionText: The normal site of implantation is one of the following:
The implantation may have the following abnormal sites except:
Regarding decidua, all statements are true except:
options: Decidua means the endometrium of the pregnant uterus.
Decidual reaction starts just after fertilization till before birth.
Decidual reaction includes growth & vaculation of stromal cells.
Decidual reaction includes vasodilatation of blood vessels.
Decidual reaction includes distension of uterine glands with secretion.

Implantation.questionText: All the following are parts of decidua except:
Regarding the process of implantation, all are true except:
options: This is the process of embedding of the morula into the uterine wall.
Its normal site is the upper part of the body of the uterus.
It starts at the 6th day after fertilization.
The endometrium at this stage is turned into decidua.
It is completed at about 9th day after fertilization.

Implantation.questionText: The process of implantation has all the following steps except:
options: It starts by adhesion of blastocyte at its embryonic pole to endometrium.
The trophoblast differentiated into outer syncytiotrophblast & inner cytotrophoblast.
The outer layer starts to erode the underlying endometrium.
The blastocyst gradually embed inside the endometrium.
The uterine hole is completely closed by uterine tissues.

Implantation.questionText: At which stage of development does a fertilized ovum undergo implantation.
Implantation is completed about the ............ day after fertilization.
The normal site of implantation is in........ of the uterus.
options: Lower part of the anterior wall of the body
Upper part of the posterior wall near the fundus
Lower part posterior wall of the body
It starts at the 9th day of pregnancy.
Chorionic vesicle is the stage that starts implantation.
It occurs at the upper part of the posterior wall of uterine cavity.
Implantation cavity is formed through the action of proteolytic enzymes produced from embryonic disc.
Is the implantation of blastocyst in the lower segment of uterine cavity.
Is the implantation of blastocyst in the uterine tube.
Is the implantation of blastocyst at the surface of ovary.
Is the implantation of blastocyst in the pelvic cavity.
It is the post-implantation endometrium at the lower segment of uterine cavity.
It is the covering of blastocyst after implantation.
It is the part of endometrium between the implanted blastocyst and myometrium.
It is the endometrium that lines uterine cavity.

Placenta.questionText: Full term placenta has all the following features except:
options: Its diameter is 15-25 cm while its thickness is 3 cm.
Its inner fetal surface is smooth.
Its outer maternal surface is irregular & formed of 15-20 cotyledons.

Placenta.questionText: The following are different steps of formation of chorionic villi except:
options: The 2 layers of trophoblast will proliferate to form processes.
These processes "1ry villi" are separated by lacunae of maternal blood.
A core of 1ry mesoderm invades these processes to form 2ry villi.
Fetal vessels will be formed within the core to form 3ry villi.
some of these villi appear more developed & called chorion leave

Placenta.questionText: Placenta will develop from all the following layers except:
Placental barrier in 1st 1/2 of pregnancy has the following layers except:
Regarding the normal placenta at birth, one of the following is FALSE:
options: umbilical cord is attached to its margin
They are composed of chorion frondosum.
They are extensions from decidual plate.
They are fixed to the chorionic plate.

Placenta.questionText: Placental barrier is the separation between:
options: Fetal and maternal surfaces of placenta.
Chorionic and decidual plates of placenta.
Fetal and maternal blood inside placenta.

Placenta.questionText: Late placental barrier is composed of:
options: Syncytiotrophoblast and endothelium of fetal blood vessels.
Cytotrophoblast and endothelium of blood vessels.

Placenta.questionText: One of the following is correct regarding the functions of placenta:
options: It allows the passage of maternal antibodies.
It prevents the passage of all viruses.

Placenta.questionText: Thin and wide placenta is known as:

Postnatal Development.questionText: All the following are different postnatal periods " in order" except:
All the following are postnatal maturation steps except:
options: 1ry oocytes kept at rest till puberty by the effect of OMI substance.
At puberty follicular cells will proliferate to form granulosa cells.
Stroma cells of ovarian cortex will condense to form sheath " theca".
Theca extrna is the main source of estrogen hormone.
Follicular antrum separates stratum granulosum from cumulus layer.

Postnatal Development.questionText: Fetal period starts at the beginning of:
The weight of fetus at full term ranges between:
At full term, the head of the fetus represents about:
Fetal movements are clearly recognized starting from:
The risky gestational period ranges between:
Fetal movements are normally perceived by the mother starting from:

Blastocyst.questionText: Regarding the process of cleavage, all are true except:
options: It means repeated divisions of the unicellular zygote by series of mitosis.
The zygote moves towards uterine lumen by cilia of uterine tube.
After 3-4 days the zygote becomes morula of 8-16 blastomers.
Finally the zona pellucida disappears in the 9th day.

Blastocyst.questionText: The process of cleavage has the following results except:
options: Decrease in size of each cell.
Differentiation of cells into outer trophoblast & inner cell mass.
starting formation of extra- embryonic mesoderm.

Blastocyst.questionText: The ............ forms after about 72 hours from fertilization and forms a solid cluster of 16 blastomeres.

options: It is formed in uterine tube within 3 days after formation of zygote.
It is formed after degeneration of zona pellucida.
It is the stage that starts implantation.

Blastocyst.questionText: One of the following is true about blastocyst
options: It starts implantation by its abembryonic pole.
It is formed 3 days after formation of the zygote.
Its inner cell mass is called embryoblast.

Trophoblast And Extraembryonic mesoderm.questionText: Regarding the 1ry mesoderm, all are true except:
options: It is loose cellular tissue separates amnion & yolk sac from trophoblast.
It arises from syncytium of the trophoblastic
The outer layer is parietal layer of extra-embryonic mesoderm.
The inner layer is visceral layer of extra-embryonic mesoderm.

Trophoblast And Extraembryonic mesoderm.questionText: For the formation of chorion, one statement is false:
options: Chorionic plate is formed of the trophoplast & somatic layer of EEM.
The blastcyst at this stage is called chorionic vesicle.
Connecting stalk connects cranial end of embryonic disc to chorion.
By expansion of amniotic cavity, chorion & EE coelom obliterated.
Through connecting stalk foetal blood passes from placenta to embryo.

Trophoblast And Extraembryonic mesoderm.questionText: The following are different steps embryonic disc except:
options: The blastocyst differentiated into outer trophoblast & inner cell mass.
The outer trophoblast shares in the formation of chorionic plate.
The inner cell mass also differentiated into 2 layers.
The superior layer has a large irregular ectodermal cells "epiblast".
The inferior layer is single low columnar mesodermal cells "hypoblast"

Trophoblast And Extraembryonic mesoderm.questionText: Formation of extra- embryonic mesoderm has the following steps except:
options: It arises from sites of meeting of trophoblast with exocelomic membrane
It fills the space between the trophoblast & the bivesicular body.
Small cavities appear within it then fuse to form EE coelom.
Extra-embryonic coelom will completely surround the bivesicular body.
EE coelom divides the mesoderm into outer somatopleure & inner splanchopleure.

Trophoblast And Extraembryonic mesoderm.questionText: Formation of EE mesoderm leads into the following changes except:
options: The yolk sac decreases in size to form 2ry yolk sac.
The allantois projects from the yolk sac to the connecting stalk.
The trophoblast unites with the somatopleure to form the amnion.
The embryonic disc is at first rounded then becomes oval.

Trophoblast And Extraembryonic mesoderm.questionText: Secondary chorionic villus is formed of:

options: The formation of trilaminar embryonic disc.
The formation of bilaminar embryonic disc.
The formation of chorion and chorionic villi.
The start of the process of folding.
The epiblast cells at the primitive streak.
Epiblast cells at the wall of primitive pit.
It persists as the annulus fibrosus part of intervertebral disc.
It lies between cloacal and buccopharyngeal membrane.
It limits the head fold during folding of the embryonic disc.
It is formed during the second week of pregnancy.

Primitive node, streak and notochord.questionText: Neurenteric canal is the communication between
Neurenteric canal is formed due to degeneration of
options: Floor of notochordal canal and underlying endoderm.
Roof of notochordal canal and median endoderm.
Roof of notochordal canal with median ectoderm.

Neural tube.questionText: Neural plate is a thickened median region of
Regarding formation of the central nervous system, mark the correct statement:
options: It is not induced by the underlying notochord.
The neural groove results from depression of the neural crest.
The first area of the neural tube to close is its caudal end.

Intraembryonic mesoderm.questionText: Somite period in pregnancy extends from:
The number of the somites on each side is:
Intraembryonic mesoderm is formed between ectoderm and endoderm at
options: On both sides of notochord and neural tube.
Median region between primitive pit and buccopharyngeal membrane.

Intraembryonic mesoderm.questionText: The age of an embryo with 16 pairs of somites is
At the occipital region, the embryo has ............ somites.

options: It is dorsolateral part of the somite.
It forms skeletal muscles behind vertebral column.
It forms three meninges around spinal cord.

Intraembryonic mesoderm.questionText: Smooth muscles of gut are developed from
One of the following is a derivative of intra-embryonic mesoderm

Folding.questionText: Regarding the folding of the embryo, one of the following is FALSE:
options: The embryo is surrounded by the yolk sac
There is a head fold and tail fold

Folding.questionText: Folding is completed by the end of.......... week of pregnancy.
Folding of the embryonic disc occurs at ............ week of pregnancy
Tail fold of the embryo is limited by
After folding, the most cranial structure in the head fold is
Before folding, the most cranial structure in the head fold is
Before folding, the most caudal structure in the tail fold is
After folding, the most caudal structure at tail fold is

options: It is separated from foregut by cloacal membrane.
It separates between Forebrain bulge and primitive umbilical ring.
It is formed before folding of the embryonic disc.

Sensory, sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia are developed from

Umbilical cord.questionText: Regarding the normal umbilical cord at birth, one of the following is FALSE:
options: It contains mucoid connective tissue Wharton jelly
it connects the fetus with the placenta

Umbilical cord.questionText: The length of the normal umbilical cord at birth is:

options: It is surrounded with amniochorionic membrane.

Umbilical cord.questionText: Physiological hernia occurs when a loop of intestine is present in the:
Abnormally long umbilical cord may lead to:
options: Early separation of placenta during delivery.
Strangulation of the baby during delivery.
Adhesion between the fetus with the wall of uterus.

Umbilical cord.questionText: Marginal attachment of umbilical cord to the placenta is known as:

Twins.questionText: All the followings are different types of mosters '''conjoint twins''' except:
Regarding the dizygotic twin, which statement is true?
Regarding monozygotic twins, which statement is true?
options: Twins are always of same sex.
Are developed by fertilization of two ova.

Chromosomal anomalies.questionText: Down syndrome most commonly results from:
options: Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5
Deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5

Chromosomal anomalies.questionText: Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is typically associated with a male phenotype and infertility?
Advanced maternal age primarily increases the risk of:

options: Partial deletion of short arm of chromosome 5
Partial deletion of long arm of chromosome 5
Partial deletion of short arm of chromosome 15
Partial deletion of long arm of chromosome 15

Chromosomal anomalies.questionText: Regarding Turner syndrome, which statement is true?
Regarding Klinefelter syndrome, which statement is true?

options: Partial deletion of long arm of chromosome 15
Partial deletion of short arm of chromosome 5
